  • gloria.cross_validation

gloria.cross_validation#

gloria.cross_validation(model, horizon, period=None, initial=None, cutoffs=None, extra_output_columns=None)#

Roll-origin cross-validation for a fitted Gloria forecaster.

For each cutoff date the model is refit to all data up to and including that cutoff, then asked to predict the next horizon period. If cutoffs=None, a sequence of equally spaced cutoffs is generated automatically using the following procedure:

  1. Start at end of training data minus horizon.

  2. Iteratively step backwards by period.

  3. Stop once the remaining training span would be shorter than initial.

Details on this method can be found in cross-validation for time series.

Parameters:

  • model (Gloria) – The fitted reference Gloria model.

  • horizon (pandas.Timedelta | str.) – Forecast horizon for each fold.

  • period (pandas.Timedelta | str | None) – Spacing between successive cutoffs. Uses 0.5 * horizon if None (default).

  • initial (pandas.Timedelta | str | None) – Minimum length of the first training window. Uses max(3 * horizon, longest_seasonality) if None (default).

  • cutoffs (list[pandas.Timestamp] | None) – Explicit cutoff dates to use instead of automatic generation. If provided, the earliest cutoff must be strictly greater than the first timestamp in the historical data, and the latest cutoff must not exceed history_end - horizon.

  • extra_output_columns (list[str] | str | None) – Additional prediction columns (beyond the defaults timestamp, yhat, and the uncertainty bounds) to include in the returned DataFrame.

Raises:

  • TypeError – If input model is not a valid Gloria object.

  • NotFittedError – If input model has not yet been fitted.

  • ValueError – If manually supplied cutoff timestamps fall outside the permissible [history_start, history_end - horizon] range.

Returns:

Concatenated forecast slices with the observed values and a cutoff column indicating the training origin for each row.

Return type:

pandas.DataFrame
